ygData.subject: Re: [neat] DARPA Grand Challenge
ygData.msgSnippet: Hmm, I got my lists mixed up. They should have read... 1) Converting sensor input into an internal model/representation of the real world. 2) Analysing that

Hmm, I got my lists mixed up. They should have read...

1) Converting sensor input into an internal model/representation of the 
real world.
2) Analysing that model and generating high level control decisions.
3) Converting high level navigation decsisions into control signals that 
drive the steering and power.

2 & 3 then can be broken down into:

1) GPS tells us the distance and brearing of the destination point. High 
level code tells next layer down these variables. Simple traditional bit 
of software.
2) Anaylsis of local terrain results in a local high-level navigation 
decision - e.g. layer 1 says go north, but there is a wall in the way, 
layer 2 analysis therefore would decide to go east.
3) Convert layer 2 output into vehicle control signals.



Colin Green wrote:

>Hi Mitchell,
>
>Not sure if you had thought of this but watching videos of the vehicles 
>made me aware of the need to model momentum and velocity. Some of these 
>vehicles are quite large and heavy and the competition required them to 
>move at an average of 25mph to complete the course within the alloted 
>time frame. Therefore any NN in the real world would be needing to make 
>decisions based on a point just ahead of the vehicle NOT the current 
>position.  One of the vehicles veers towards the cameraman (safely 
>behind a concrete barrier) and then brakes abruptly just before the 
>barrier - the AI displayed good knowledge of the vehicle's breaking 
>distance! (or perhaps just luck)
>
>I tend to think that this kind of problem can be decomposed into 
>distinct layered functions:
>
>1) GPS tells us the distance and brearing of the destination point. High 
>level code tells next layer down these variables. Simple traditional bit 
>of software.
>2) Analysing that model and generating high level control decisions.
>3) Converting high level navigation decsisions into control signals that 
>drive the steering and power.
>
>2 & 3 then can be broken down into:
>
>1) Converting sensor input into an internal model/representation of the 
>real world.
>2) Anaylsis of local terrain results in a local high-level navigation 
>decision - e.g. layer 1 says go north, but there is a wall in the way, 
>layer 2 analysis therefore would decide to go east.
>3) Convert layer 2 output into vehicle control signals.
>
>
>It's my opinion that the sort of simplified models we tend to use for 
>NEAT type projects are ideally suited to evolving NN based controllers 
>that can be used for the high level control decisions AND the very low 
>level stuff such as converting the local navigation task into control 
>signals to drive the vehicle. The stuff in between such as building of 
>the physical world model from sensor data is more suited to traditional 
>software development, though it's also worth a try.
>
>Each of these tasks on it's own is (hopefully) a reasonably simple model 
>and can be evolved/developed independently of the others - and when put 
>together I see no reason why they wouldn't be applicable to the real 
>world problem of controling a real vehicle.
>
>Colin.
